SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES,
No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Craburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: ERNEST HENRY PLUMMER
Present Address: ROCKAVILLE
Pioneer Address: BANGOR
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1903

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Many or few? Always or sometimes?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sometimes, sometimes.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

5. Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Did you always bring something to eat?

6. Was there an occasion when people came unexpectedly?

7. What was the term used to describe parties used or was some other expression common?

8. Did you ever have "bees" then groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

9. Tell what you remember about such gatherings, having happened if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

10. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes?

11. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by the same home one house to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first five years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? How was your visit arranged if any?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? How often?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

5. What time of the day did you go? - In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

6. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Did you always bring something to eat? Did someone stay home to work after the place?

7. Did the whole family go? Or did someone stay home to work after the place?

8. Did you ever have women who groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Tell what kind of activity it was, where it was held, and how long it lasted.

9. Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible. Tell what the reasons were for, and how often they occurred.

10. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whisky drives or dances in homes? Describe. How many couples were there?

11. They mixed game clippety cards. We had a "hurricane" dance which gave us much pleasure.

12. Boys' learning instruments of various kinds. Give dates.

Were those more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by some one home another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, etc., other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree planting, etc.)

9. How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe. Give dates.

10. What material was it made of? Who built it? The municipality, some organization, etc.? How large was it? How old is it?

11. Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country school? For what purpose did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.)
Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances. Your answers.

8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances. Your answers.

9. What was your first school hall built? How large was it? Who built it? The community hall was built by the school district organization etc. It was built in the village or town or was it a country hall? School hall was built by the school district organization etc. It was built in the village or town or was it a country hall?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? How were babies and small children provided for? How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? In what large enough for house but not large enough for dancing? What card games were popular in the early days?

11. Was there card playing for a prize? What dances were popular? Squares, all the old time dances.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? No, there was no difficulty among adults in planning parties.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. I think most everyone except the education made other arrangements for the amusement.
3. Has the church been in your community? If so, how long?

12. What activities did you participate in? (e.g., Bible study, prayer meetings, social events)

13. Describe what you remember about church services, telling how often they were held.

14. Describe any other details of visiting parties, etc., that you remember, such as games or entertainments not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates/times when such entertainments took place.

15. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

16. Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? How many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
3.

What activities at formal (i.e., or "social") do you remember in small towns, both in past years and into our own calling, calling cards visited through the years all socially toward the end.

13. Are the churches known in your community? How much effort was made to describe what you remember about churches, telling how often they were used, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any places or events not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Nearly all these events to the former within the Canadian Prairies.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community?

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers Club in your district?

Tell when it was organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities, its aims and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only from the town, or was open to people within a school district, or was open to the entire county, or was open to the entire surrounding community, or was a branch of the church question (many organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before the church was founded. Give dates when it was first organized. Its nature (social, religious, educational, etc.), its purpose (for example, what it did), who started it, how many people attended, etc.

19. What means were commonly used by these organizations for raising money?

20. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

21. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? If so, describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lanterns and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (e.g., skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (e.g., skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? What games were played indoors in winter card games such as "Happy Families", "Alphabets" or others, checkers or other games? Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PIONEER AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

How long did it continue?

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

READING
